clinical-medical.name: Clinical & Medical
clinical-medical.description: Disease data, clinical trials, phenotypes, and medical genetics

databases.name: Catalogue of Somatic Mutations in Cancer
databases.description: COSMIC is the world's largest and most comprehensive resource for exploring the impact of somatic mutations in human cancer. It contains manually curated data from the scientific literature and large-scale sequencing projects.
databases.license: Free for academic use, license required for commercial use

databases.name: cBio Cancer Genomics Portal
databases.description: cBioPortal is an open-access resource for interactive exploration of multidimensional cancer genomics data sets. It provides visualization, analysis, and download of large-scale cancer genomics data from multiple studies.
databases.funding: NCI, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center

databases.name: ClinVar
databases.description: ClinVar is a freely accessible public archive of reports of relationships among human variations and phenotypes with supporting evidence. It aggregates information about genomic variation and its relationship to human health, facilitating access to interpretation of variants for clinical care.

databases.name: Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man
databases.description: OMIM is a comprehensive, authoritative compendium of human genes and genetic phenotypes. It contains information on all known Mendelian disorders and over 16,000 genes, with a focus on the relationship between phenotype and genotype.
databases.license: Free for individual use, license required for redistribution

databases.name: Orphanet
databases.description: Orphanet is a European reference portal for information on rare diseases and orphan drugs. It provides high-quality information on rare diseases, clinical trials, medicinal products, expert resources, and patient organizations.
databases.funding: European Commission, French Ministry of Health

databases.name: The Cancer Genome Atlas
databases.description: The Cancer Genome Atlas is a landmark cancer genomics program that molecularly characterized over 20,000 primary cancer and matched normal samples spanning 33 cancer types. It generated over 2.5 petabytes of genomic, epigenomic, transcriptomic, and proteomic data.
databases.license: Open access with controlled access for some data

genomics.name: Genomics
genomics.description: Genome sequences, variations, annotations, and comparative genomics

databases.name: ArrayExpress
databases.description: ArrayExpress is a database of functional genomics experiments that stores data from high-throughput functional genomics experiments. It includes gene expression data from microarray and sequencing platforms.

databases.name: BLUEPRINT Epigenome
databases.description: BLUEPRINT is a European project that aims to generate at least 100 reference epigenomes from distinct types of hematopoietic cells from healthy individuals and their malignant leukemic counterparts. It provides comprehensive epigenomic data for blood cell types.

databases.name: DNA Data Bank of Japan
databases.description: The DNA Data Bank of Japan is one of the three partners of the International Nucleotide Sequence Database Collaboration (INSDC), along with GenBank and ENA. DDBJ collects and provides public access to nucleotide sequence data and related information.

databases.name: Encyclopedia of DNA Elements
databases.description: ENCODE is a comprehensive catalog of functional elements in the human and model organism genomes. The project aims to identify all functional elements including genes, transcripts, and regulatory regions.
databases.organism: Human, mouse, and other model organisms

databases.name: Ensembl
databases.description: Ensembl is a comprehensive genome browser for vertebrate genomes that supports research in comparative genomics, evolution, sequence variation and transcriptional regulation. It provides automatic annotation of genome sequences and integrates data from multiple sources.

databases.name: European Nucleotide Archive
databases.description: The European component of the International Nucleotide Sequence Database Collaboration (INSDC), providing a comprehensive record of the world's nucleotide sequencing information. ENA exchanges data daily with GenBank and DDBJ.

databases.name: GenBank
databases.description: The NIH genetic sequence database, an annotated collection of all publicly available DNA sequences. GenBank is part of the International Nucleotide Sequence Database Collaboration (INSDC) and exchanges data daily with its partners to form a comprehensive global archive.

databases.name: GENCODE
databases.description: GENCODE produces high-quality reference gene annotation for human and mouse genomes. It is the default gene annotation for the human genome used by the Ensembl and UCSC Genome Browsers.

databases.name: Gene Expression Omnibus
databases.description: GEO is a public functional genomics data repository supporting MIAME-compliant data submissions. It stores high-throughput gene expression and genomics data including array- and sequence-based data, serving as an archive and resource for gene expression studies.

databases.name: Genome Aggregation Database
databases.description: The Genome Aggregation Database is a resource developed by an international coalition of investigators that aggregates and harmonizes exome and genome sequencing data from a variety of large-scale sequencing projects.

databases.name: miRBase
databases.description: miRBase is the primary online repository for miRNA sequences and annotation. It provides a comprehensive searchable database of published miRNA sequences and annotations with information on genomic location and predicted targets.

databases.name: NCBI RefSeq
databases.description: A comprehensive, integrated, non-redundant, and well-annotated set of reference sequences for genomes, transcripts, and proteins. RefSeq serves as a curated, value-added layer built from primary archives like GenBank.

databases.name: NIH Roadmap Epigenomics Mapping Consortium
databases.description: The NIH Roadmap Epigenomics Mapping Consortium produced a public resource of human epigenomic data including reference epigenome maps for stem cells and primary ex vivo tissues. It includes integrative analysis of 111 reference human epigenomes.

databases.name: Rfam
databases.description: Rfam is a database of RNA families represented by multiple sequence alignments, consensus secondary structures, and covariance models. It provides comprehensive annotation of non-coding RNA families.

databases.name: RNAcentral
databases.description: RNAcentral is a comprehensive database of non-coding RNA sequences that provides a single access point to 44 RNA resources and over 18 million ncRNA sequences from a wide range of organisms and RNA types.

databases.name: Sequence Read Archive
databases.description: The Sequence Read Archive is NCBI's primary archive of high-throughput sequencing data. SRA stores raw sequencing data and alignment information from next-generation sequencing platforms.

databases.name: Single Nucleotide Polymorphism Database
databases.description: A public archive for short genetic variations such as single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), insertions, deletions, and other small-scale variations. dbSNP serves as a central repository for genetic variation data from humans and other organisms.

databases.name: UCSC Genome Browser
databases.description: An interactive genome browser and suite of tools for visualizing, comparing, and analyzing genomic data. The UCSC Genome Browser integrates sequence and annotation data from multiple sources and provides powerful visualization capabilities.
databases.organism: Multiple organisms (human, mouse, and many others)

databases.name: PubMed
databases.description: A free resource comprising more than 39 million citations and abstracts for biomedical literature from MEDLINE, life science journals, and online books. PubMed is the primary gateway to scientific biomedical literature.

metabolomics.name: Metabolomics
metabolomics.description: Metabolites, metabolic pathways, and biochemical reactions

databases.name: Chemical Entities of Biological Interest
databases.description: ChEBI is a dictionary of molecular entities focused on small chemical compounds. It provides a comprehensive resource of chemical entities of biological interest with ontological classification and structural information.

databases.name: DrugBank
databases.description: A comprehensive, expert-curated pharmaceutical knowledgebase containing detailed information on drugs, drug targets, and drug actions. DrugBank combines chemical, pharmacological, and pharmaceutical data with comprehensive drug target information.
databases.license: Free for academic use, commercial license available
databases.funding: Genome Canada, Canada Foundation for Innovation, University of Alberta

databases.name: Human Metabolome Database
databases.description: The Human Metabolome Database is a comprehensive, high-quality, freely accessible, online database of small molecule metabolites found in the human body. It contains over 220,000 metabolite entries including both water-soluble and lipid-soluble metabolites.
databases.funding: Genome Canada, Canadian Institutes of Health Research

databases.name: MetaboLights
databases.description: MetaboLights is a database for metabolomics experiments and derived information. It provides a repository for metabolomics data including raw spectral data, metadata, and protocols following community standards.

databases.name: METLIN Metabolite Database
databases.description: METLIN is a metabolite mass spectral database containing over 960,000 compounds. It provides tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) data and is widely used for metabolite identification in untargeted metabolomics experiments.
databases.license: Free for academic use, subscription for commercial use

databases.name: PubChem
databases.description: The world's largest free database of chemical information, including structures, properties, and biological activities. PubChem provides information on chemical structures, identifiers, properties, biological activities, patents, and health and safety data.

databases.name: FlyBase
databases.description: FlyBase is a comprehensive database for Drosophila genetics and molecular biology. It includes data on genes, alleles, phenotypes, genetic and physical interactions, reagents, sequences, genetic maps, expression, images, and literature.

databases.name: Mouse Genome Informatics
databases.description: MGI is the international database resource for the laboratory mouse, providing integrated genetic, genomic, and biological data to facilitate the study of human health and disease. It is a comprehensive resource for mouse genetics and genomics.

databases.name: Rat Genome Database
databases.description: RGD is a collaborative effort between leading rat researchers and bioinformaticians to collect, consolidate, and integrate rat genomic and phenotype data. It provides tools and resources for rat, mouse, and human comparative genomics.
databases.organism: Rattus norvegicus (rat), with mouse and human data

databases.name: Saccharomyces Genome Database
databases.description: SGD is a scientific database of the molecular biology and genetics of the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. It provides comprehensive integrated biological information for budding yeast along with search and analysis tools.

databases.name: WormBase
databases.description: WormBase is an international consortium of biologists and computer scientists dedicated to providing the research community with accurate, current, accessible information concerning the genetics, genomics and biology of C. elegans and related nematodes.

databases.name: Zebrafish Information Network
databases.description: ZFIN is the zebrafish model organism database that provides a wide array of expertly curated, organized and cross-referenced zebrafish research data. It serves as the central zebrafish genetics and genomics resource.

databases.name: Gene Ontology
databases.description: A comprehensive, computational model of biological systems that provides structured, controlled vocabularies for gene product functions. GO provides three orthogonal ontologies: molecular function, biological process, and cellular component.

databases.name: BioCyc
databases.description: BioCyc is a collection of Pathway/Genome Databases for thousands of organisms. It includes organism-specific databases that contain curated metabolic pathways, regulatory networks, transporters, and other cellular functions.
databases.license: Free for academic use, subscription for commercial use

databases.name: Biological General Repository for Interaction Datasets
databases.description: BioGRID is a biomedical interaction repository containing protein and genetic interactions, chemical associations, and post-translational modifications from major model organism species.
databases.funding: NIH, Canadian Institutes of Health Research

databases.name: IntAct Molecular Interaction Database
databases.description: IntAct provides a freely available, open source database and toolkit for the storage, presentation and analysis of molecular interaction data. It is part of the International Molecular Exchange consortium.

databases.name: Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes
databases.description: KEGG is a comprehensive database resource for understanding high-level functions and utilities of biological systems from molecular-level information. It integrates genomic, chemical, and systemic functional information, particularly known for its pathway maps.
databases.license: Free for academic use, subscription for commercial
databases.organism: All organisms (emphasis on completely sequenced genomes)

databases.name: MetaCyc
databases.description: MetaCyc is a curated database of experimentally elucidated metabolic pathways from all domains of life. It contains over 2,900 pathways from more than 3,000 organisms and is widely used for metabolic pathway prediction.
databases.license: Free for academic use, license required for commercial use

databases.name: Reactome
databases.description: A free, open-source, curated, and peer-reviewed pathway database of human biological processes and reactions. Reactome provides detailed molecular-level descriptions of biological pathways and their cross-references to other resources.
databases.funding: NIH, EMBL-EBI, Ontario Institute for Cancer Research

databases.name: STRING
databases.description: A database of known and predicted protein-protein interactions, including direct physical and indirect functional associations. STRING integrates data from numerous sources including experimental evidence, computational prediction, and literature mining.
databases.funding: SNSF, ELIXIR, CPR, University of Zurich

databases.name: WikiPathways
databases.description: WikiPathways is an open, collaborative platform for biological pathway curation. It enables researchers to create, update, and share pathway diagrams in a wiki-based format with community contributions.

proteomics.name: Proteomics
proteomics.description: Protein sequences, structures, functions, and interactions

databases.name: InterPro
databases.description: An integrated database of protein families, domains, and functional sites that combines signatures from multiple member databases. InterPro provides a unified classification system for proteins by integrating Pfam, PROSITE, SMART, and other resources.

databases.name: neXtProt
databases.description: neXtProt is a comprehensive human-centric protein knowledge platform that integrates and disseminates protein-related information. It focuses on human proteins and includes extensive functional annotations, variants, and disease associations.

databases.name: Pfam
databases.description: A large collection of protein families, each represented by multiple sequence alignments and hidden Markov models (HMMs). Pfam is one of the foundational resources for protein domain classification and is integrated into InterPro.

databases.name: PROSITE
databases.description: PROSITE is a database of protein families and domains that consists of entries describing protein domains, families and functional sites, as well as amino acid patterns and profiles to identify them.

databases.name: Protein Data Bank
databases.description: The Protein Data Bank is the single worldwide archive of structural data of biological macromolecules, containing information about experimentally-determined structures of proteins, nucleic acids, and complex assemblies. It serves as a central resource for structural biology.

databases.name: PRoteomics IDEntifications Database
databases.description: PRIDE is a repository for mass spectrometry-based proteomics data and is one of the founding members of the ProteomeXchange consortium. It stores raw mass spectrometry data, identification results, and quantitative data.

databases.name: Swiss-Prot
databases.description: Swiss-Prot is the manually annotated and reviewed section of the UniProt Knowledgebase. It provides high-quality, non-redundant protein sequence annotations with a high level of integration with other databases.
databases.funding: SIB Swiss Institute of Bioinformatics, EMBL-EBI, PIR

databases.name: TrEMBL
databases.description: TrEMBL contains computationally analyzed protein sequences from the translation of coding sequences in the EMBL-Bank/GenBank/DDBJ databases. It provides automatic annotation and classification awaiting full manual annotation in Swiss-Prot.
databases.funding: SIB Swiss Institute of Bioinformatics, EMBL-EBI, PIR

databases.name: UniProt
databases.description: UniProt is the Universal Protein Resource, providing comprehensive, high-quality, and freely accessible protein sequence and functional information. It consists of UniProtKB (reviewed Swiss-Prot and unreviewed TrEMBL), UniRef, and UniParc.
databases.funding: EMBL-EBI, SIB Swiss Institute of Bioinformatics, PIR
